Amino acid-based ionic liquids for CO2 conversion to form cyclic carbonate under solvent-free conditions Shuang Yue a ⁎ Xiu-Jia Hao b Ping-Ping Wang b Jun Li b a Institute of Rare and Scattered Elements Chemistry, Liaoning University, Shenyang 110036, China Institute of Rare and Scattered Elements Chemistry Liaoning University Shenyang 110036 China b College of Chemistry, Liaoning University, Shenyang 110036, China College of Chemistry Liaoning University Shenyang 110036 China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The amino acid ionic liquids of 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium aspartic acid [bmim][ASP], 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium glutamic acid [bmim][Glu], N-octyl-N-methylmorpholinium glutamic acid [mor1,8][Glu] and N-hexylisoquinolinium aspartic acid [HiQuin][ASP] have been synthesized and characterized by 1H NMR, 13C NMR and IR spectroscopy. The catalytic performance of the amino acid ionic liquids for the coupling of various epoxides and CO2 to produce cyclic carbonates was studied. The influence of anion type, catalyst dose, reaction temperature, reaction time and CO2 pressure on the yields of cyclic carbonates was examined. The synthesized ionic liquids were found to be single component bifunctional catalysts in good yields and selectivity, no additional organic solvent required and halogen free. Furthermore, this system provides a reasonably environmentally benign chemical process in terms of potential industrial application. Keywords Amino acid ionic liquids Cyclic carbonates Carbon dioxide Epoxides Catalysis 1 Introduction Carbon dioxide is an attractive C1 building block in organic synthesis as it is easily available, non-toxic, economical and inexpensive C1 resource [1–5], Therefore, the utilization of CO2 as a feedstock for chemicals is a good idea. Currently, the synthesis of cyclic carbonates via the cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides is the most common utilize [6–8]. Cyclic carbonates can be used in many applications areas such as industrial raw materials, aprotic polar solvents, electrolytic elements of lithium secondary batteries, monomers for synthesizing polycarbonates, and intermediates for the pharmaceutical and fine chemical industries [9–11]. The reaction of epoxides with CO2 has attracted much attention. In the last decades of the 20th century, a large number of catalysts have been exploited, such as vary from alkali metal salts or metal oxides [12–14], molecular sieves [15], transition metal complexes [16–22], quaternary ammonium salts [23], metal-organic frameworks [24–26], main-group organometallic compounds [27,28], phosphonium salts [29–33], gold nanoparticles or cross-linked polymeric nanoparticles [34,35] and ionic liquids [36–44]. In particular, ionic liquid is an ideal catalyst for the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides [45–50], because they possess some of the most important features. Notably, Deng Sun et al. [36] showed imidazolium functional ionic liquids were a good choice for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates from carbon dioxide and epoxides. What's more, with imidazolium cations and halogen anions for cyclic carbonate synthesis, the catalytic activity of ionic liquids could be greatly enhanced by the presence of Lewis acidic co-catalysts [51]. While it is not vastly accepted as a “green” reaction because the halogen ionic liquid is harmful to the environment [52,53]. Hence it is one of the most attractive topics on the research of the bio-renewable natural compounds partly being ions of ionic liquids. The amino acid ionic liquids (AAILs) consisting of amino acid anions have unique properties such as containing multi-functional groups, chirality, high thermal stability, low cost, biodegradable and biocompatible [54]. Therefore, we have successfully synthesized single component bifunctional amino acid-based ionic liquids in which [bmim][ASP] and [bmim][Glu] are reported in the literatures [55,56]. Moreover, the synthsized ionic liquids have been utilized as halogen-free catalysts for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates from CO2 and epoxides (Scheme 1 ), which requires no additional organic solvent. 2 Experimental 2.1 General remarks All preparations were performed under laboratory atmosphere. All reagents and solvents employed were commercially available and were of analytical grade. [L-Glu](99.99%) was purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagents Co. Ltd of China. Anion-exchange resin (type 717) was purchased from Shanghai Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd. and activated by the usual method. IR spectra were recorded on a Nicolet 5700 FT-IR spectrometer using KBr as the IR matrix. 1H NMR and 13C NMR were measured in DMSO with a mercury-VX 300 spectrometer and bruker avance Ⅲ 600MHz. Thermogravimetry coupled with mass spectroscopy (TG-MS) was conducted utilizing a Netzsch TG209 system; typically about 10mg of each sample were heated from 25°C to 800°C at 10 Kmin−1. The analyses of organic products were conducted with gas chromatography on a CP 3800 instrument equipped with a FID and a capillary column (30m×320μm×1μm) CP-Sil 19 CB. TOF-MS spectra were measured on a Bruker micrOTOF_Q. 2.2 Preparation of the ionic liquids 2.2.1 General preparation of ionic liquids 1-2 1-Butyl-3-methylimidazolium aspartic acid [bmim][ASP](1) and 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium glutamic acid [bmim][Glu](2) were synthesized according to literature processes [55,56]. 2.2.2 General preparation of ionic liquid 3 N-Octyl-N-methylmorpholinium bromide [mor1,8][Br] was synthesized according to literature processes [57]. A total of 5g of [mor1,8][Br] passed through the anion-exchange resin (type 717) [58], to prepare the [mor1,8][OH] solution. The [mor1,8][OH] solution was reacted with a slight excess of Glu (2.5g) through neutralization at room temperature for 24h. Subsequently, water was removed by rotary evaporation. To this reaction mixture was added 90mL of acetonitrile and 10mL of methanol, and it was stirred vigorously. The mixture was then filtered to remove excess Glu. Filtrate was evaporated to remove solvents. Finally, the products were dried at 80°C under vacuum for 12h before being used for further characterization and using. 2.2.3 General preparation of ionic liquid 4 N-Hexylisoquinolinium bromide [HiQuin][Br] was synthesized according to literature processes [59]. A total of 5g of [HiQuin][Br] passed through the anion-exchange resin(type 717), to prepare the [HiQuin][OH] solution. Then [HiQuin][OH] solution was reacted with a slight excess of ASP (2.5g) through neutralization at room temperature for 24h. Subsequently, water was removed by rotary evaporation. To this reaction mixture was added 90mL of acetonitrile and 10mL of methanol, and it was stirred vigorously. The mixture was then filtered to remove excess ASP. Filtrate was evaporated to remove solvents. Finally, the products were dried at 80°C under vacuum for 12h before being used for further characterization and using. 2.3 Characterization ILs 1–4 were characterized by FT-IR, 1H NMR, 13C NMR spectroscopy and can be found in the Supporting Information. The ionic liquid as a catalyst (0.3mol% with regard to epoxide) was introduced into a reactor containing epoxide (5.0mL) at room temperature without using any co-solvent and co-catalyst. The reactor vessel was placed under a constant pressure of carbon dioxide and then heated to 130°C for 12h. After the reaction, the reactor was cooled to room temperature, and the excess of CO2 was vented, and the mixture was evaporated under vacuum. The residuals were purified using silica gel column chromatography (eluent: dichloromethane) to give the corresponding cyclic carbonate. The cycloaddition products are known compounds and were characterized by TOF-MS. 2.5 Representative procedure for catalyst recycling After the reaction, the catalyst ([bmim][ASP]) was recovered and separated by vacuum distillation, dried at 80°C for 12h under vacuum, and then reused for the next run. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization The amino acid ILs 1–4 (seeTables 1-2and Supporting Information) were synthesized via exchange of bromide by hydroxide anions on an ion exchange resin, subsequent addition of amino acid and stirring at room temperature for 24h. All four ILs were characterized by FT-IR, 1H NMR and 13C NMR (see Experimental section). All ILs can be handled in atmosphere and stored in desiccators prior to use without decomposition. 3.1.1 NMR spectroscopic characterization The ILs 1–4 were characterized by 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectroscopy (in d6-DMSO). The spectra of 1–4 show no impurities detectable by 1H NMR and 13C NMR. For the ILs 1–2, the chemical shifts are in agreement with the report in the literatures [55,56]. For the IL 3 (Fig. 1 ), methylene (–CH2–) protons adjacent to the nitrogen atom appear in the range 3.42ppm and the methyl (–CH3) protons adjacent to the nitrogen atom appear in the range 3.12ppm.In 1H NMR spectrum of 4 (Fig. 2 ), the isoquinoline ring protons are observed in the 8.03–10.28ppm ranges due to the conjugated effect of phenyl ring and pyridine ring. Similarly, some 13C NMR shift changes for the carbon atoms in ILs 3–4 can be observed (Tables 1 and 2 ). These shift changes are in agreement with a changed coordination situation. 3.1.2 Vibrational spectroscopy FT-IR spectra were used to clarify the structure of the amino acid anions. All four ILs show similar IR spectra with respect to CO bond stretching (seeTable 3and Supporting Information). The CO vibrations are found in the region 1600cm−1. The values are in good accordance with those published in the literature [60]. The ν(CH) stretching vibrations of the morpholine CH groups are located in the region 1393cm−1. The methylene groups can be observed in the region 2862–2926cm−1. The characteristic band at 1341cm−1 is mainly assigned to methyl. The morpholine ring CC and CN stretching vibrations are found in the region 1270cm−1. In addition, the IR spectra of the 3 show another new band at 1115cm−1, which is assigned to stretching vibration of COC group in the morpholine ring [61,62] (Table 3). The isoquinoline ring CC stretching vibration is found in the region 1508cm−1. The isoquinoline ring CN stretching vibration is found in the region 1638cm−1. Band at 3072cm−1 is attributed to the ν(CH). The new peaks appeared at 1319cm−1 and 2873∼2917cm−1, these are the characteristic absorption peaks of mainly methyl and methylene groups. The isoquinoline ring CC and CN stretching vibration bands are observed at 1262cm−1 [63] (Table 3 ). 3.2 Effect of reaction conditions To optimize the reaction conditions, the effects of various reaction parameters were tested, and the results are summarized in Table 4 . It can be observed that no product was detected in the absence of catalyst under the applied reaction conditions (entry 1). The influence of reaction temperature on chloropropene carbonate yield was investigated (entries 5–7, Table 4). The results show that the yield of chloropropene carbonate was increased with increasing the reaction temperature and the optimal performance was achieved at 150°C. Therefore, higher temperature favors the epoxide ring opening and insertion of carbon dioxide into the CO bond of epoxide is converted to cyclic carbonate. Although the [bmim][ASP] as catalyst at 150°C has high catalytic activity, 130°C could be considered to be an appropriate reaction temperature from an economic standpoint. It was indicated amino-functional ionic liquids can be stable, and used at up to 150°C temperature, being well agreement with the heatresistant property(see Supporting Information Fig. S1–4), labelled as one of this type AAILs’ advantages. The effect of CO2 pressure on the reaction was also evaluated (entries 5, 8–10, Table 4). The yield of chloropropene carbonate was decreased by an increase the pressure, but the yield of chloropropene carbonate changes little, while would decrease to 97% when further increasing the pressure up to 3MPa (entry 9). The results show that the pressure has little effect on the yield of chloropropene carbonate. Additionally, the influence of reaction time on the chloropropene carbonate yield was given in Table 4 (entries 2–5). It was observed that the reaction time had a remarkable effect on the reaction. From the results, it can be seen that the yield of chloropropene carbonate was increased with increasing the reaction time, and almost quantitative yield (98%) could be achieved after 12h. That is to say, [bmim][ASP] could be an effective catalyst for synthesis of cyclic carbonate. Therefore, the suitable reaction time would be 12h. Under our standard reaction conditions (130°C, 0.5MPa, 12h, 0.3mol% catalyst relative to epoxide), the four amino acid ionic liquids obtained in high yields (more than 98%). We compared the yield of the reaction after 5h on the [bmim][ASP] and [bmim][Glu] (entries 3, 14, Table 4). The results show that the [bmim][Glu] (yield 97%) has high yield of chloropropene carbonate than [bmim][ASP] (yield 84%), this might be because Glu has one more carbon. The result indicates that anion carbon chain growth will help yield improving. Furthermore, we also compared the yield of [bmim][Glu] and [mor1,8][Glu] (entries 14, 15, Table 4) under the same conditions. We found that the yield of chloropropene carbonate almost unchanged. The result suggested that cation has little effect on the reaction. Moreover, we studied the catalytic activity of the precursors of the ionic liquids 1-4 ([bmim][Br], [mor1,8][Br], [HiQuin][Br]) when the reaction time is 5h and 12h respectively. Comparatively, amino-functional ionic liquids ILs 1–4 exhibited a superior activity to traditional halide-based ILs, a raising(about 5%) on the yield of chloropropene carbonate was observed when the reaction time is 5h (entries 3, 14–19). However, prolonging the reaction time to 12h, the yields of chloropropene carbonate were almost same. (entries 5, 11–13, 20–22). Table 5 compares the results of carbonate synthesis using various ionic liquids as catalysts reported in the literatures. Previously reported systems required the halogen ionic liquid or co-catalyst to accomplish satisfactory results. However, the negative effect of halogen on surroundings is one of the main causes for those ionic liquids with halogen anion being challenged as ‘green’ candidates. Although a direct comparison between the various efficient ionic liquids for cyclic carbonate synthesis is tedious owing to the differences in the reaction conditions, we noticed that single component bifunctional amino acid-based ionic liquids could be utilized as halogen-free, cocatalyst-free, and solvent-free catalysts for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates from CO2 and epoxides in good yields and selectivity under mild conditions. 3.3 Scope of the reaction Under the optimized reaction conditions (130°C, 0.5MPa, 12h, 0.3mol% catalyst relative to epoxide), the scope of application of the catalyst was examined. A series of epoxides were explored for cyclic carbonate synthesis in the presence of [bmim][ASP] and the results are depicted in Table 6 . The catalyst was found to be applicable to various terminal epoxides to provide the corresponding cyclic carbonates in high yields (more than 96%) with excellent selectivity (up to 99%). And the activities of the substrates were not sensitive to the properties of the substituent in the substrates. 3.4 The Reusability of the Catalyst For a potential application in a green and economic process the recyclability of a catalyst plays an important role. To examine the stability and the longevity of the catalytic system, the reaction of CO2 with epichlorohydrin was carried out under the reaction conditions (T=90°C, t=12h, P(CO2)=0.5MPa). The recovery of the catalyst is easily achieved by vacuum distillation. As shown in Fig. 3 , the activity of the catalytic system remains the same for at least five catalytic cycles and no obvious decrease of chloropropene carbonate yield was observed. The results indicate that the prepared catalysts exhibit good stability for CO2 cycloaddition reaction to carbonate. 3.5 Catalytic kinetics study and mechanistic investigation Insight into the reaction mechanism was obtained from a series of kinetic studies. The synthesis of chloropropene carbonate was chosen as the model reaction to investigate the kinetics of the IL 4 reaction. For the synthesis of cyclic carbonates, it is credible that CO2 is first order according to the previous study [71–73]. Therefore, the rate equation for a reaction can be written as Eq. (1). in which k represents the rate constant, [epoxide], [CO2] and [IL 4] represent the epichlorohydrin, CO2 and the catalyst concentrations, respectively; a and b represent the orders of the reactants. Since the concentrations of CO2 were kept constant in our experiments, Eq. (1) can be expressed as Eq. (2) or Eq. (3) as needed. (1) r = k [CO2] [epoxide] a [IL 4] b (2) r = k obs1[epoxide]a, k obs1 = k [CO2][IL 4] b (3) r = k obs2[IL 4] b , k obs2 = k [CO2] [epoxide] a To determine the reaction order of epichlorohydrin, experiments were carried out at four different epichlorohydrin concentrations, as shown in Fig. 4 . All the kinetic experiments showed good fits to first order kinetics, implying that the reaction is first order for epichlorohydrin. The same method was used to determine the order with respect to the catalyst. The reaction was carried out under varying concentrations of catalyst and comparison of the observed rate constants for the four experiments indicated a first-order reaction in catalyst (Fig. 5 ). This is consistent with a rate-determining step involving both catalyst, epoxide, and CO2. The kinetics studies showed that the synthesis of chloropropene carbonate catalyzed by IL 4 obeys the rate shown in eqn (4) as follows: (4) r = k [CO2] [epoxide][IL 4] In addition, for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates, pioneering studies have shown that the amine group of ionic liquid was inclined to react reversibly with CO2 to afford the ammonium carbamate as reactive intermediate[67,74,75]. 13C NMR was adopted to verify the CO2 reaction state (see Fig. 6 ). In addition to the peaks of pure IL 4, no new peaks appeared. And The C chemical shifts in IL 4 before and after CO2 reaction are almost unchanged. The results seem to indicate that CO2 inserts directly into the ring-opened intermediate. Based on previous report [50,64–70,76–80] and the results in our study, a possible mechanism was proposed, as shown in Scheme 2 . The epoxide molecule may be activated by the cation in the bifunctional catalyst via interaction of the cation with the oxygen atom, therefore the amino acid anion might simultaneously attack the less hindered carbon of the epoxide, hence resulting the ring-openning. While insertion of CO2 into the ON bond may give anion to the alkyl carbonate, which might leading subsequent cyclization via an intramolecular nucloephilic attack, and accordingly, realized the formation of cyclic carbonate and regeneration of the catalyst. Accordingly, the catalyst showed cooperative effect of both amino acid anion and cation on the catalytic activity. 4 Conclusions The single component bifunctional catalysts were developed to be effective catalysts for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates from carbon dioxide and epoxides under green and economic conditions. And the activities of the substrates were not sensitive to the properties of the substituent in the substrates. The catalysts showed high thermal stability and selectivity, and moreover, the catalysts could be applicable to other terminal epoxides. These characteristics make them ideal catalysts in terms of potential industrial application in the synthesis of cyclic carbonates from epoxides and CO2. coredata.dc:description: The amino acid ionic liquids of 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium aspartic acid [bmim][ASP], 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium glutamic acid [bmim][Glu], N-octyl-N-methylmorpholinium glutamic acid [mor1,8][Glu] and N-hexylisoquinolinium aspartic acid [HiQuin][ASP] have been synthesized and characterized by 1H NMR, 13C NMR and IR spectroscopy. The catalytic performance of the amino acid ionic liquids for the coupling of various epoxides and CO2 to produce cyclic carbonates was studied. The influence of anion type, catalyst dose, reaction temperature, reaction time and CO2 pressure on the yields of cyclic carbonates was examined. The synthesized ionic liquids were found to be single component bifunctional catalysts in good yields and selectivity, no additional organic solvent required and halogen free. Furthermore, this system provides a reasonably environmentally benign chemical process in terms of potential industrial application.
coredata.dc:title: Amino acid-based ionic liquids for CO2 conversion to form cyclic carbonate under solvent-free conditions
